sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix:

\begin{bmatrix}
a & b & c \\
d & e & f \\
g & h & i
\end{bmatrix}

In our case, the matrix is:

\begin{bmatrix}
4 & 2 & 1 \\
2 & 0 & -3 \\
1 & -3 & 2
\end{bmatrix}

So, a = 4, b = 2, c = 1, d = 2, e = 0, f = -3, g = 1, h = -3, and i = 2.

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

det(A) = 4(0*2 - (-3)*(-3)) - 2(2*2 - (-3)*1) + 1(2*(-3) - 0*1)
det(A) = 4(0 - 9) - 2(4 - (-3)) + 1(-6 - 0)
det(A) = 4(-9) - 2(7) + (-6)
det(A) = -36 - 14 - 6
det(A) = -56

So, the determinant of the given 3x3 matrix is -56.
